description: From Anglo-Norman aloper (“to abduct, run away”), itself borrowed from Proto-West Germanic *andihlaupan (“to run away”). Equivalent to and- +‎ lope as well as and- +‎ leap (these being doublets). More at lope.

verbs.description: elope (third-person singular simple present elopes, present participle eloping, simple past and past participle eloped)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, of a married person) To run away from home with a paramour.

(intransitive, of an unmarried person) To run away secretly for the purpose of getting married with one's intended spouse; to marry in a quick or private fashion, especially without a public period of engagement.
(intransitive, dated) To run away from home (for any reason).
examples: If we'd been a bit quicker, we could have caught Gowan before he eloped
